output.conclusion: This course has provided an in-depth exploration of electromagnetic fields, equipping you with the advanced knowledge and analytical skills necessary to tackle complex problems in electromagnetics. You are now prepared to contribute to cutting-edge research and development in this fascinating field.
output.courseTitle: Electromagnetic Fields: Advanced Concepts and Applications
output.introduction: Welcome to Electromagnetic Fields: Advanced Concepts and Applications. This course is designed for individuals with a strong foundation in electromagnetics seeking to deepen their understanding and explore advanced topics. We will delve into complex mathematical formulations, explore real-world applications, and challenge your problem-solving abilities.

chapters.chapterTitle: Review of Maxwell's Equations and Constitutive Relations
chapters.description: A concise review of Maxwell's equations in both differential and integral forms. Discussion of constitutive relations for various materials (linear, nonlinear, anisotropic) and their impact on electromagnetic field behavior.

chapters.chapterTitle: Electromagnetic Potentials: Scalar and Vector Potentials
chapters.description: In-depth analysis of scalar and vector potentials. Gauge transformations (Coulomb and Lorenz gauges) and their implications. Retarded potentials and their application to time-varying fields.

Proof and application of the uniqueness theorem for electromagnetic fields. Detailed discussion of boundary conditions at interfaces between different materials. Applications to solving electromagnetic problems.

chapters.chapterTitle: Plane Wave Propagation in Lossy Media
chapters.description: Analysis of plane wave propagation in lossy dielectrics and conductors. Skin depth and its frequency dependence. Polarization effects and Brewster's angle.
Detailed analysis of wave propagation in rectangular and circular waveguides. TE, TM, and TEM modes. Cutoff frequencies and mode excitation.

chapters.chapterTitle: Optical Fibers: Mode Analysis and Dispersion
chapters.description: Introduction to optical fiber waveguides. Mode analysis in step-index and graded-index fibers. Dispersion mechanisms and their impact on signal propagation.

chapters.chapterTitle: Antenna Fundamentals: Radiation Patterns and Gain
chapters.description: Basic antenna parameters: radiation pattern, directivity, gain, and impedance. Friis transmission equation and link budget analysis.

chapters.chapterTitle: Antenna Arrays: Phased Arrays and Beamforming
chapters.description: Analysis of antenna arrays. Phased array concepts and beamforming techniques. Applications in radar and communication systems.

chapters.chapterTitle: Specialized Antennas: Microstrip and Dielectric Resonator Antennas
chapters.description: Introduction to microstrip and dielectric resonator antennas. Design considerations and applications in wireless communication.
Introduction to the Finite Element Method (FEM) for solving electromagnetic problems. Formulation of the FEM equations and application to static and dynamic fields.
Introduction to the Method of Moments (MoM) for solving electromagnetic problems. Application to antenna analysis and scattering problems.
Introduction to the Finite-Difference Time-Domain (FDTD) method. Implementation and application to wave propagation and scattering problems.
Introduction to Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC) and Electromagnetic Interference (EMI). Sources of EMI and coupling mechanisms.
Detailed discussion of shielding and grounding techniques for EMC compliance. Design considerations for effective shielding and grounding.
Overview of EMC standards and regulations (e.g., FCC, CISPR). Compliance testing and certification procedures.
Introduction to metamaterials and their unique electromagnetic properties (e.g., negative refractive index). Applications in cloaking, superlensing, and perfect absorbers.
Introduction to plasmonics and surface plasmon polaritons. Applications in sensing, imaging, and energy harvesting.
Discussion of current research topics in electromagnetics, such as topological electromagnetics, non-reciprocal devices, and quantum electromagnetics.
